text: Shared at gregwilsonstl house, next to regular Everett. It poured a black color with a dark brown head. The aroma was of dark roast, bitter chocolate, caramel, malts, light smokiness, dark fruits and booze. The taste was similar to the aroma with more dark chocolate, roast, caramel, tobacco, licorice, light smokiness, wood, dark sweet fruits and loads of booze. Really tasty.

Sampled at GregwilsonStLs tasting. Had this along side the regular. Aroma is not that substantial but the flavor is very nice. It is sweet with a lot of chocolate. Bourbon and heat. So rich and really good. This is delicious. I assumed it was an imperial stout.
Totally different then regular. Richer than regular. More chocolate. Tasted at my "numbers and names" bottle share.

Bottle... Pours black with a mid-sized, creamy, beige head. Good retention. The aroma features roasted grains, dark chocolate, oak and a hint of vanilla. Medium-bodied with airy carbonation. The flavor offers fruitiness, booziness and brownie brittle. Bittersweet, deeply roasted finish. Bottle shared by growler!

Bottle, split with jamesy at a super secret location. This is a lot more restrained than most barrel aged beers on the market, and a lot more subdued than I was expecting. The sweetness comes through in this more than in the regular Everett, giving it a flavor profile more like a sweet Russian Imperial Stout than a porter. Medium-low amount of bourbon flavor from the barrel aging, which adds some depth. Quite good.
Damn! Happy Birthday to me. Unbelievably good. Bourbon, oak and nuts?? on the nose. Roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla, oak, maple syrup. Drinks big. Reminds me of a BA Jackie Os beer. Damn.
Bottle shared at Jasons. Big chocolate notes and big bourbon taste and nose. Just a really fantastic experience.
Bottle shared. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Notes of toast, fudge, sweet chocolate, bourbon, bitter roasty coffee.

Bottle shared by a friend. Pours black with a medium tan head. Nose of malt, raisin, bourbon, chocolate and plum. Malty flavor giving way to creamy chocolate and raisin before a slightly boozy finish that tastes more like brandy than bourbon.

July 14, 2016. Bottle, bottled 12.9.15, received in a trade, thanks!  Black with a small brown head. Aroma is malty with toffee, caramel, noted of prunes, smooth roasted coffee, hints of licorice, bourbon, vanilla. Taste is medium sweet, malty, light roasted. Finish is sweet caramel, some vanilla, prunes, figs, bourbon, smooth roast with coffee, light chocolate. Medium bodied, soft, fine carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. 
Great balance.

Bottle courtesy of HackoBock. Pours viscous dark blackish brown with a fairly small dark mocha head that leaves some spotty trac e on the glass while dissiapting. Smell is malty with roasted malts, dark bread, caramel, charred wood, dark roast coffee, dark chocolate, moist soil, liquorice fudge, soot and hints of bourbon alcohol and green chili. Taste is sweet, slightly bitter, tiny salty and malty. Mouthfeel is slightly viscous, round, tiny roasted astringent, very tiny boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with bready roasty malts, dark chocolate, bourbon and hints of plums in brandy. Tasty and very complex. Very balanced between the base beer and barrel. A treat only bugged by the light green chili in the nose.

Bottle at TradeBookCon #04 160714. Opaque black beer with a nice lasting beige/brownish head. Roasted chocolate aroma, vanilla, bourbon, woody, dark chocolate, raisins, caramel, licorice, spicy notes, figs, some cream. Chocolate flavor, raisins, woody, subtile bourbon, cream, spicy notes, licorice, some cocoa powder. Well hidden alcohol, very complex beer.
A: Pitch black with a thin light brown lacing. N: Bourbon, vanilla, coffee, chocolate T: Toffee, vanilla, milk chocolate O: Lovely... Some alcohol heat and very nice...

Bottle 12.09.15 drank to "celebrate" my wedding anniversary celebrated alone... Aroma: great nose of bourbon, chocolate, oaky, vanilla, a tad of paraffin. My kind of aroma. App: really dark brown with burgundy tint, small spearing brown head, little lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, creamy, velvety, medium high sweetness, a bit of anise, dry sweet and subtle bitter finish. Overall: good stuff. Think its a tad too boozy and way too sweet for me. Still enjoyed every sip of it but at this price point, Id rather buy 3 original Everett over this one. Anyway, for how Im feeling tonight, this really does the job done.

Partagée en compagnie des trois amigos. Liquide noir et huileux dont les premiers millilitres dans les verres ne formèrent aucune mousse alors que le fond de la bouteille fut pour sa part bien mousseux et dense. Forte variation tant au niveau présentation, quolfactif que gustatif entre les différents niveaux de liquide dans cette même bouteille. Dans lensemble le liquide me paraît encore trop jeune. Beaucoup de bourbon et de mélasse et peu de nuances. Un liquide délicat comme Everett, à 8% dalcool qui plus est, souffre à mon avis dun vieillissement si prolongé. En effet, ce dernier sen est trouvé durement aminci et ses splendides nuances chocolatées, réduites à peu. Le bourbon a tout dérobé sur son passage et cest bien triste. Une acidité de baies rouges due au bois et à lalcool. Une bière qui demeure un très bon porter barriqué, mais qui ne fait absolument pas le poids devant la merveilleuse Everett originale.

Bottle. Black viscous our with dense mocha head. Aroma is chocolate, ash, vanilla, and oak. Taste is full on chocolate fudge, vanilla, oak, just a ton of barrel in this. Very rich, cant really taste any of the regular beer in this but man, its very decadent.

Bottle shared by guests @ Brouwcafé de Molen. Pours a very dark brown, deep black beer with a small tanned head on top. Aroma has massive roasty bourbon woody notes, thick molasses, vanilla and caramel. Flavor is very sweet with loads of sugary notes, molasses and bourbon. Great oak aging going on here. Silky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Amazingly sweet and long balanced aftertaste. Awesome stuff!!

Bottled on 12/9/15
Tasted on 4/28/16 from a capped 500mL bottle, big thanks to Drews for sharing. Pours very dark brown with a thin brown head that doesnt stay around for long. The nose is a very lightly nuanced caramel, vanilla, candied nuts, and light baking spices with all of the classic dark chocolate, coffee, and cocoa nibs from the base Everett. The flavor is, once again, very balanced, caramel, maple, candied nuts, some heat from the bourbon, with dark chocolate syrup and coffee, just the right amount of bitterness. The body is full and creamy with light carbonation and a long lightly bitter, caramel, maple, and toffee finish.

Bottle at home. Pour is pitch black with a frothy tan head and sticky lacing. Big caramel, toffee, some tobacco, leather, cocoa nibs, coffee, slightly earthy, and licorice in the aroma. Taste is big tobacco, black licorice, some anise, cocoa nibs, lightly smoky, some toffee, bourbon, light oak, and raisins with a touch of heat on the backend. Thick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Creamy and full bodied, decent smoke notes and lots of leather. Tasty, but not better than the original.

500 ml bottle thanks to Chris. Pours a jet black color with a medium brown head. A big sweet boozy bourbon nose. A really sexy label. Big sweet vanilla and toffee bourbon, a really lovely creamy palate. Dark fruit, ash, caramel. Very smooth. Loads of dark fruit, ash, even a bit milky. Damn good. So well made.

Bottle, December 2015 release. Pours inky opaque black, small creamy brown head, good lacing. Aroma is cocoa, molasses, anise, bourbon, vanilla. Flavor is medium plus sweet, light plus bitter. Full body, creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle. Thanks Tim! Aroma is intense oaky bourbon with underlying chocolate and molasses. Tastes delicious. Oak, vanilla, chocolate syrup, coffee beans, light coconut and molasses. Insane mouthfeel. So silky smooth and slightly syrupy. Great beer.

500 ml v2016 (3 weeks old) bottle shared with friends at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki, from trade with Frank. Black color with brown head. Malty aroma, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, chocolate, fruity, wood. Sweet and light bitter taste, milk chocolate, brownie, fruity, coconut and vanilla, apple brandy?! Great!! Full silky creamy body with soft carbonation.
Pours opaque black wit a large white head which soon recedes. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, coffee. Taste is oak, vanilla, cocoa bitter, coffee bitter, caramel sweet, molasses. Full body.

Sampled from bottle @ "Het is allemaal de schuld van Koen" tasting. Opaque pitch black color, average sized brown head. Aroma is malts, bourbon, alcohol. Taste malts, bourbon, again quite heavy on the alcohol, quite boozy, roast, liquorice bitter, nice bitter finish. Medium body and carbonation. Nice, but a bit too boozy.

bottle shared by a friend. poured a deep brown to almast black colour with a small but lasting tanned head on top. aroma is very strong sweet chocolate forward. with a very clear strong notice of sweet bourbon, raisins, vanilla, oak, and quite some hot alcohol booze. sticky caramel, and sweet toffee notes. taste is still quite hot, even after 2 years. cant imagine how how this would be at the beginning, very bourbon forward, medium modied.
Bottle @ joes goes whale hunting. Black with a small beige head. Smells alcohol, boozy, roasty, sweet. Tastes roasty, chocolate, sligbtly alcohol, wood. Pretty nice. Full body, soft carbo.

500 mL bottle. Bottled 02/2014. Originally reviewed 6/10/2014/

Black. Nice khaki head. Thick collar.

Smell is Bourbon. Lots of oak. Nutty malts and chocolate. A little bit metallic.

Taste has a strong bourbon flavor, but not a strong alcohol flavor from it. Rich chocolate. Woody. Vanilla. And then more wood. That metallic flavor has turned into astringent wood.

Very woody. Medium heavy. Medium carbonation. No heat from the barrel.

 Its overpowered by bourbon, but I dont necessarily think thats a bad thing.

Magnum shared by Adam C on 7/25/15.Deep, dark, porter-colored liquid (just coined that term) is of indeterminable clarity, though assumedly pretty clear, as Shawns non-IPAs usually drop bright. Tan head is good-sized and well-retained.We had a pretty good discussion about barrel aging while we were all drinking this guy and my position was of this being right on the border of my tolerance (for bourbon apparency). On one hand, the bourbon notes are not harsh/boozey and the barrel itself isnt heavily tannic, but its still quite dominant overall, pushing out a lot of potential beer character in the nose. Spicy bourbon, dry coconut and sweet vanilla are all prominent. Roast takes a backseat, but enough maltiness helps keep it balanced (balanced in the sweet vs. dry sense, not balanced in the bourbon vs. beer character sense). With warming, I did get a bit of fusel/glue-like heat.Full, soft, luxurious body is definitely a strong point here. The milk chocolate-like flavors of Everett are here dried out by the barrel, producing a more reserved, dark chocolate-like character replete with vanilla from both barrel and malt. Spicy bourbon washes over the palate, as well, and char and coconut are felt, helping to balance the big malt profile. Pleasant enough bourbon flavor and again its not sharp or raw (though theres a touch of heat here, for sure), but I just think its a bit too heavy-handed, overall, on the bourbon character. Would prefer significantly less, or better yet, none! Why change Everett, its nearly a perfect porter!

Poured from magnum thanks AdamChandler for the Ratebeer Farmhouse Magnum Tasting. Dark chocolate pour with a nice tan head. Aromas of chocolate caramel vanilla and bourbon. Taste is insane. Huge notes of bread burnt caramel vanilla and a nice balanced alcohol finish.

50cl bottle pours an oily, murky black with some spitty, off white head. Nose has a whole lot of barrel, char, smoke, some fusel alcohol, a little charcoal, some chocolate and some bready/dopple notes. Flavor has some chocolate sweetness, some burnt caramel, char, some mild vanilla, a little cola, some mild berry. Oily finish. A bit much for me and perhaps too much time in the barrel.

16.9 oz bottle. Dark brown with a tan haze. Nose is bourbon, smoke, chocolate, prune and oak. Creamy with bright carb then airy and warming. Taste is more about the whiskey than the base brew but softened by the chocolate and coffee.

[ Bottle ][ 500mL ][ Trade ][ Trade ][ Riedel Vinum XL Pinot Noir ][ 2.17.15 ]
>> Pours clear sepia brown looking inky black in the glass. Oversized head with higher than expected carbonation. Head retention minimal, looks a bit foamy. Nose is outstanding vanilla, soft barrel, buttercream chocolate frosting, coconut, birthday cake. Taste begins with rich flavors on the front of the palate (chocolate shake, cake frosting), moving to a bland/dead mid-palate, and finishing with stinging tannic astringency and papery hints of oxidation. A bit disappointing. Maybe this one didnt age too well in the bottle.

From notes. 500mL bottled 2/2014, shared with Amanda. Pours thick, dark brown with a big chocolate brown head. Looks amazing. Aroma is dark chocolate, fig, bourbon, vanilla. Flavor is dark chocolate, a hint of coffee, bourbon, oak and vanilla.

Jan tasting with the crew. I love bourbon and they definitely made a hugh profile here. A lot of the super bold original was hidden. Not so bold, but lots of vanilla, with light roast, big nose of whiskey, smooth. And then I did write down "tight".
Big whiskey and bourbon bite aroma. Lots of the same in the flavor. Afraid the porter gets a little drowned out by the barrell. Chalky gritty texture. Would probably do better with a little more age.

500ml bottle. Black with a frothy brown head. Flavors are coffee, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, ketchup, dark fruits and alcohol with vinous and oaky notes. Medium body, moderate carbonation, oily texture.

Bottles 500ml (both 2014 batches)
Pours pitch black with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of chocolate, wood, bourbon, coffee. Taste is of chocolate, lots of alcohol, coffee, bitterness, roasted malt. Palate: Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Overall: Lots of alcohol. Complex. A sipper for sure, but never cloying.

bottles thanks to john_beer and tom10101 - february and may 2014! pours very dark brown with a creamy reviving dark beige head, leaving very ncie lacing. sweetish burnt nuts and delicious browned malts, roasted coffee, bourbon, wooden cherries, chocolate-covered raisins - actually more raisins are found in may bottling, molasses and maple syrup, some resinous and woody-astringent notes. average carbonation - both versions would benefit from less bubbles, warming if not boozy - surprisingly for may version being hotter, sweetish and spicy-resinous-woody finish. much enjoyed! whilst rating is slightly higher for ba version, i would still prefer non-ba everett on a regular basis. the other one as a tasty sit-back-and-relax winter sipper.

We did a side by side of the two versions released in 2014 but I didnt really take notes separately for each of them so this rating is me going back and forth between the two. Pours a dark brown with a medium beige head rim that leaves good lacing. Nose is of coconut, bourbon, chocolate and the February release has a definite raisin edge to it. Taste is of vanilla, chocolate, bourbon and other alcohols. There is a medium bitterness and a lot of oak, too. Body is medium-full, carbonation moderate and mouthfeel just really smooth. My Everett memories tell me that I liked the regular better but it is still a really good bourbon porter!

Bottles (500 ml). We had the 02-2014 and 05-2014 releases side-by-side. February released was shared by Jean-Michaël, thanks! The appearance for both are almost identical, almost black with a small fully lasting brown head and little lacing. Aroma of the 02-2014 release is super chocolate forward with bourbon, raisins and boozy notes. The 05-2014 is boozier and quite perfume. Taste of the 02-2014 is also chocolate forward with a well intagrated bourbon presence, caramel, alcohol and light acidic notes. Taste of the 05-2014 is similar, but with more perfume notes and boozier. Body of both are medium and carbonation are moderate/medium. The 02-2014 has a bourbon/chocolaty finish while the 05-2014 has a boozy finish. Overall, the 02-2014 is much more complex, more balanced, less boozy and more enjoyable than the 05-2014, but regular Everett is better than both. Score for 02-2014 is 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0 and for the 05-2014 is 7-4-7-3-15 = 3.6

Was hoping for much more than what was in the bottle. Nose is full of bourbon oak. Palate is masked by a highly effervescent carbonation. Dry smokey flavor with very little notes of the barrel on the palate.
Huge bourbon nise and aroma. Rich dark chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla and dark fruits. A sipper.

500ml bottle, first release of 2014, pours dark brown black with finger of tan head. Nose is bourbon forward but not boozy, lots of rich earthy dark fruit, raisin and some bitter cocoa. Taste is dark fruit, bourbon layered spice, some light oaky coffee, licorice, raisin. Finish is chocolate, coffee, dark fruit spice, bourbon. Very tasty and well executed but didnt knock my socks off, almost prefer regular everett.

Bottle, first batch released in 2014. Black pour with mocha head. Aroma is intense on bourbon, coffee, vanilla and cinnamon. Taste is chocolate, bourbon, caramel and butterscotch. Palate is light and creamy and carbonation is light. This is bourbon bomb which is surprising since it is the batch that spent less time into the barrel. Good but a little too intense for my liking. I much prefer the regular Everett.

Bottle, from notes. Thanks to Jeff, for the beer and all the hospitality. We owe you! Pours dark brown, short-lived tan head. Vanilla; figs; a lot of toast; marshmallow and a bit of smoke. Chocolate. Taste: soy, metal; tannic, oaky, almost astringent. Dark fruit, cola. Moderately sweet, nutty, alcohol astringent finish. Cola. Chalky texture. Bourbon and wood. A lot of bourbon. Overall: seems to land sort of right where a lot of these do. Nice beer, glad to have tried it.

My Bottom Line:
Powerful bourbon envelops dark chocolate and roast in this richest of Porters.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam tops the pure darkness.
-Bourbon vanilla sadly overpowers this brews usually wonderful malt signature.
-The body is lush, never too obese.
-Candied fruitiness is found throughout as well.
-This ones not as complex as the 2011 version, but it makes for a great dessert beer nonetheless. One to share, definitely.

Bottle; gros merci Martin et Michèle!

Bottle at SSAN V, 18 months on oak. Opaque black pour with creamy brown foam. Aroma of bourbon, pretty bourbon forward, nice rich vanilla notes, very oaky, light spicy notes, good whisky, chocolate. Tastes a lot like bourbon, lots of alcohol, chocolate notes, light roastiness, not very sweet at all, attenuated but I would have used a bit more malty sweetness to support the bourbon, bourbon is a bit too dominant. Palate is medium bodied with good carbonation. Good.
Bottle. Moderate character of bourbon in the flavor and aroma. Very heavy roast, and a thick, heavy palate. A good porter, but unfortunately ruined by bourbon.

Thanks to Johnsense for sharing. Heavy black pour, foam dissipates with little lacing. Sweet bourbon nose, black cherry and cassis liqueur. Barrel dominates the flavour, and the porter cant quite stand up to it. Finishes sweet with a hint of cigar

13th August 2014Tasting at Jacks RAH Annexe! Thanks to Leighton for this one. Opaque dark brown beer, small pale tan head. Palate is light and dry with fine carbonation. Dry and fairly thin dark malts. Spicy alcohol and bourbon. Whisper of oak. Dry finish. This continues to be a curiousity, once again the barreling doesnt appear to have done much for the lovely base beer. Its not bad though.

500mL bottle, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is hugely bourbony, with lots of roast and a touch of coffee. Flavour is complex as hell, with loads of heavily roasted malt and moderate bourbon that doesnt dominate. Excellent use of battles to amp up an already kickass beer. Carbonation is slightly more aggressive than the base beer. Excellent beer.

Dark brown with a good brown head. Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, wood, molasses, touch of soy sauce, hint of anise. Medium bodied, slightly velvety mouthfeel, complex on the palate with a touch of booze on the finish. Taste is bourbon, chocolate, wood, molasses, hint of soy. Delicious.

Bottle: Inky black center, shades of dark brown at the edges with a mocha-tan foam on top; bubbly & quick to reduce to a thin ring. Aroma of fudge brownie batter, Devils food cake coated in a bourbon-vanilla reduction. Spicy oak, salted caramel, moderate notes of musty wood, & a slight kiss of anise on the back-end. Rich, velvety. Super dark chocolate flavor; approaching 86% cacao territory with a side of warm & spicy bourbon. Imagine double dark chocolate fudge brownies, covered with brown sugar, drizzled with vanilla & bourbon, then baked for a little too long. Deep roast, char. Get get a touch of coffee in the finish, too, along with long lasting notes of wood, booze, & bitter dark fudge. A great barrel aged porter. I think this one would get even better with some time to mellow & meld.

Une bouteille partagée. Un liquide presque noire avec une belle tête beige foncée. Un nez de bois, fruits rouges, whiskey. Une bouche simple, peu agressive, note de chocolat, cerises, finale sur la poussière. Simple.

Une bouteille obtenue via un échange avec Didier. Merci! Beau liquide visqueux avec une tête brune qui finit tranquillement par quitter mon verre. Au nez, le bourbon apporte une belle richesse caramélisée et vanillée ainsi quune dimension épicée (cannelle) aux notes chocolatées, fruitées et fumées existantes. Ça ouvre lappétit! En bouche, le liquide chaud et boisé pousse les malts sur le bord du précipice : cest malheureux de tomber ainsi dans une barrique et de sy noyer. En bouche, le corps de la bière est définitivement dense avec une armée de bulles très fines et une texture veloutée. La finale est alcoolisé et persistante, pleine de bourbon et de bois noir. Bouquet des plus intéressants mais saveurs bien écrasées par la barrique. Pas mauvais mais rien à voir avec la sublime version originelle.

Dark brown pour, thick tan head. Very carbonated. Nose is booze, a touch vinous, chocolate, somewhat metallic and vegetal. Taste is a touch vinous, fresh water, rich chocolate, dark fruits. Medium creamy mouthfeel. Wow, did not expect a HF BA dark beer to be so damn good.

Bottle dated 02/2014. This has some great bourbon and wood aromas, but also has a baked bread character as well. The chocolate and roasted notes in the regular version are covered over by the bourbon barrel flavors. I love barrel aged beers and I like this one too. Just not too much.

Bottle at Chateau Jackl, big thanks to to HF bro Leighton for yet another, 13/08/14.
Black with a moderate tan swirl and edgeing.
Nose is a big dark fruit charabang, bourbon infusion, red berry tang, dates, booze tunes, dark toffee notes.
Taste comprises raisens, dates, molasses, very subtle spice, sweet jammy dark berry fructis, light cocoa wash.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with light roast and a touch of bourbonics.
Solid.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Le liquide est sombre, filiforme et laisse une tete fuyante se dissoudre au dessus de lui. Larome est formidable mais en même temps si loin de la matrice si parfaite et voit la vanille supporter les petits fruits, le chocolat et la chaleur dalcool. Le corps est vraiment aminci mais chargé dune dose raisonnable de sucre. Lalcool perce et je perçois difficilement les repères de loriginale. Lente, riche mais délicate dégustation.

Bottle shared by Bacterial. Dark black pour, little carbonation and a smoky soy aroma. Flavor is also a bit of soy, light prune, red wine, hints of earthy chocolate and warming alcohol on the finish. Outstanding beer, at any price.
Malzig alkoholischer Antrunk, in dem die Fasslagerung deutlich wird. Die Alkoholnoten bleiben ersichtlich, stören aber im Verlauf weniger. Vanille, zum Ende brennend. 11/10/8/10/10/9

Bottle shared by me - thanks!!

Thick black pour with a tan head. Nose is bourbon and roasted malt, smoked wood, alcohol. Really nice mouthfeel. Thick but still dry. Big bourbon goodness. Smoky. Oaky. Really yummy.
Bottle shared by Jeff - thanks! Dark brown with some deep reddish highlights. Bourbon, wood, mild smoke, charred marshmallows, some vanilla. Moderate palate. Delicious.

Brought back from the brewery on a trip to Vermont. A lot of pleasure drinking this. But, a lack of complexity in aroma and flavors had it lost a few points. 
Alcool et Bourbon frappent dabord le nez. Présence de chocolat, de cerises noires, un peu de bois. Lalcool est cependant dominant. Le nez est un peu moins complexe que ce à quoi je mattendais. Le visuel est noir, opaque; comme une stout. Avec une petite mousse mince.
Lalcool est également très présent en bouche avec encore une fois le chocolat et les cerises. Cest comme manger une Cherry Blossom alcoolisée. Lalcool nest toutefois pas déplaisant malgré son intensité. On y retrouve un peu de café mais cest encore le chocolat qui domine. La texture est très onctueuse et les saveurs restent longtemps en bouche. Beaucoup de plaisir à boire cette bière. Mais un peu plus de complexité en olfactif et en saveurs aurait fait plus honneur à leur réputation.

Bottle, cheers to Leighton! Deep brown pour with a tiny head. Pretty woody. Peanut butter and kit kat bars. Vanilla and bananas fosters. The taste is of sweet brown sugar. Cinnamon spice. Vanilla and chocolate fudge. Hot woody finish. Quite carbonated, sort of detracts from the drinking experience a bit. Still very tasty.

Bottle shared in London - procured in VT. Pours black-brown with a frothy beige head. The nose has charred wood, baking cocoa, alcohol, earth. Medium sweet flavor with some toasty toffee, burnt marshmallows, dark fruits, scorched earth, mild burnt wood. Medium to full bodied with average to lively carbonation. Warm to hot finish with lots of burnt toffee, earth, gooey charred marshmallows, milk chocolate. Good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2014 Bottle thanks to Leighton. It pours black with a thick tan head. The nose is rich, roast, toast, earth, burnt brown sugar, nougat, unripe coconut and toast. The taste is rich, earth, roasty, acidity, toasty, spice, wood, alcohol, coconut and vanilla with a dry finish. Full body, fine carbonation and oily mouth-feel. Dunmo... Not quite there. Base beer is great, but this is not quite there.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 Chocolate pour with fine bubbled mocha foam. Soft, fulsome bourbon aroma with shades of coconut, butter toffee, corn cakes and caramel. The black cherry and cinnamon bark porter malts compose the sound foundation.
The flavor is luxurious and bourbon forward, finding its gentle warmth without flashing alcohol. There is a solvent-like plain chemical note in the middle that is more bland than offensive, and this is washed away quickly in the rich brown sugar cordial tide that builds into the long, velvety finish. Red berries, chocolate and tobacco bathe in the bourbon for a good while after swallowing.

High carbonation here works well with the medium weighted body to differentiate this from all the dessert-like sippers of this ilk. That it finds many of the same flavors and textures without being a syrupy, burdensome task to drink is satisfying.

500 bottle shared by yourefragile, thanks Michael. Pours a dark brown/nearly black, with lasting beige edge head. Aroma is roasted malt, smoke, bourbon, and bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is delicious and massive - bourbon booziness with bitter chocolate and malt with tobacco leaf vegetal notes. Booze snap in the finish - delicious.

Bottle shared by yourefragile. Thank you Michael.

The beer is dark brown, nearing black, with a lasting beige collar. The aroma offers bourbon, oak, roast, chocolate. Silky smooth. Lovely flavor. A graceful warming alcohol note in the finish. Chocolate and bourbon with a slight edge (good) to it. Fabulous.

500ml bottle in a tulip. Pours black with a lacy, tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, bourbon and oak and vanilla, some dark chocolate and hints of coffee, and light dough. Flavor an incredible blend of everything. Smooth texture. A really good beer, you know, just another amazing dark, barrel-aged beer by Hill Farmstead.

Another thank you to Matt for another great hill farmstead beer. 500 ml bottle, dated May 2014. Released a week ago. This one has a lot of barrel. Lots of oak, touch of vanilla. Bourbon taste but no bourbon heat. Some chocolate and coffee but not as much as in the base version. Carbonation was a little strong when first poured. This is a decent ba beer, but after having the regular one fresh from the growler, I have to say the barrel didnt improve it.
Black pour, brown head. Aroma has tons of bourbon... flavor is bourbon, chocolate and alcohol. Pretty straightforward but absolutely delicious.

Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast, dark chocolate, oak. Medium mouthfeel with rich roasted malt, dark chocolate, light wood and bourbon, easy to drink, very impressive.
Caramel, chocolate, light spice, espresso, and leather. Complete but balanced sweetness with some coffee bitterness. Lively carb, full bodied but a little thinner, and rich.

hazy sepia, thin cream head with light lacing, oily top. Biting licorice and chocolate in nose, tons of oaty roast. Front Is licorice and oak heavy, light booze, light oat and chocolate mid with minor sweetness, very low acidity from roast. Light chocolate note through rich, dusty, full bodied finish. Increase integration and attenuation.

Pour is black with a dark caramel head. Nose is wood, bourbon, olive, and notes of some rich caramel and chocolate malt. Taste is similar, strong bourbon notes with a good bit of slightly charred wood. Malts arent super strong, some caramel, hints of olive, and notes of sweetness in back. Finish is a hint hot, lots of booziness, well carbonated and full bodied.

Very confused by this one.. I would much rather have straight up Everett any day of the week. Massive mocha bubbles. Carbonation is way to sharp lending a weird dryness to the palate. The oak character is overpowering. I love BA stouts and porters but this is probably one of the worst Ive had. Reminded me of some central waters shit.
Pours a dark black/brown with a light brown head. The smell is coconut, vanilla, bourbon alcohol. The taste is bourbon, vanilla, alcohol, dry and roasty. The body is medium with nice carbonation.

bottle thanks to Matt. Huge aroma, tons of bourbon barrel, but absolutely perfectly balanced with the rich roasty body of everett. Tons of lingering roastyness as the sweetness of the barrel aging resides. Awesome stuff.

Bottle shared by the Port-Land crew, thanks guys. Dark brown pour with a mocha head, bourbon and dark roasted malt notes. A bit effervescent, really bourbony but without the heat. Dark roasted malts, chocolate, and caramel notes. Oak lowlights. Good body and mouthfeel.
Great ba porter. Supremely drinkable, lightly bourbony with subtle vanilla, cocoa, coffee, sweet malts and light hops. I love this.
Bottle thanks to Bobby at Monday Night Tasting. Pours dark brown with tan head. Nose/taste of oak, roast chocolate, orange cognac, vanilla and chocolate cake. Medium body.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with tan head. Super bourbon, chocolate, roasted aromas. Chocolate, roasted, and bourbon/oak flavors.

Pours a deep burnt umber color with three fingers of fizzy khaki foam. Nose is bourbon heavy with nice spicy vanilla, chocolate cake, touches of roast charred wood and licorice. Palate follows with tons of bourbon character, nice malted milk, spicy booze, smooth cocoa and layers of complex dark fruit, earthy roast. Delicious !

500 ml Bottled on 02/2014. Aroma nice subtle bourbon, Cocoa, vanilla and a touch of oak. Tan head with bubbles, soapy lace with light retention. 
Flavors of layered malts, dark fruit, brown sugar, cocoa upfront with nice subtle vanilla bourbon in the back end. Hints of licorice and molasses and nice lingering dry roasted character. Great flavor with a nice oil texture that allows it to slide down the gullet. Damn nice drinker!

New entry for 2014 (different barrels used as confirmed by the brewer)

A - Pitch black, light 1 finger coffee head, sticky chocolate darkness.

S - Nose is big roasted chocolate toffee, figs and prunes. Feeling all geriatric on the nose here. 

T - Lots of fresh crema, touch of sweet candy peppermint or licorice. Chocolate cake and roasted espresso beans covered in cocoa.

M - Creamy, thick mouthfeel, minor abv taste hits the final finish

O - Having this one much fresher than the last BA everett variant and I think I like it almost identically.

Bottle, cracked with Al during gunners fa cup win. Pours black with medium beige head. Taste is char, bitter grain, coffee, tobacco, dark cocoa, and hops. Aroma was most of the same with milk chocolate, malt, pine hops, cigars and some bourbon barrel richness. Never got sweet and maintained a hoppiness, cheech ah.

Huge thanks to Dmac for sharing this bottle. Pours out a decent brownish color with a small off white head. Aroma is of chocolate, light coffee, mild bourbon, wood, light sweetness. Taste is complex and smooth with a silky mouthfeel. Flavors of light bourbon, chocolate, coffee, tasted grains, syrup, light brown sugar, sweet woody notes, brownie mix, mild vanilla. Super beer.
